title: [K-12] Ecopsychological Approach for Athletesâ€™ Self-Regulation and Competition Preparation: Mathematics-Based Simulation Utilizing Probability Models, Optimization Equations, and Statistical Validation

context.prior_knowledge: Foundations in exercise physiology, basic sports psychology theories, nonlinear pedagogical concepts, elementary statistics (mean, variance, standard deviation), probability concepts, linear/nonlinear equation interpretation, and graph analysis (histograms, scatter plots)
context.additional_context: Development and assessment of self-regulated learning strategies through real-game simulations in a BYOD environment. Learners analyze and predict performance data using mathematical tools (equations, probability models, optimization algorithms) and quantify decision-making accuracy based on simulation outcomes.

learning_goals: Learners can design personalized competition preparation strategies using mathematical modeling that incorporates probability distributions and optimization equations by applying nonlinear pedagogical principles.
Learners can improve self-regulation skills by over 80% by transforming training environments using constraint-led approaches, considering probabilistic variables and confidence intervals.

Learners can build performance prediction models (math-based simulations) under conditions similar to actual competition venues and conduct statistical validation, including regression analysis and hypothesis testing.

Learners can derive optimization equations (utilizing calculus and matrix operations) that improve decision-making accuracy by 30% under psychological pressure by applying an ecological psychological framework.
difficulty: Hard - Complex requirements with multiple constraints
